content.text:
As discussed, a List is a type, hence it is an object that has particular properties and particular methods that it can perform. Let's look at some of them below.

## Indexing

Lists use zero-based indexing. This means that the first element of an array is located at the **0th** index.
content.mdHtml:
As discussed, a List is a type, hence it is an object that has particular properties and particular methods that it can perform. Let’s look at some of them below.

Indexing

Lists use zero-based indexing. This means that the first element of an array is located at the 0th index.

content.text: Since each element has its own position, a list can contain duplicates of a single element because each duplicate is still unique in its position. For instance, we can have a list with five identical elements because even though the value of each element is the same, they all are still unique and can be differentiated amongst each other through their position in the list.
content.mdHtml: Since each element has its own position, a list can contain duplicates of a single element because each duplicate is still unique in its position. For instance, we can have a list with five identical elements because even though the value of each element is the same, they all are still unique and can be differentiated amongst each other through their position in the list.

content.text:
## Accessing an Element

To access an element at a particular index we can use square brackets (`[]`).

The general syntax is as follows.
content.mdHtml:
Accessing an Element

To access an element at a particular index we can use square brackets ([]).

The general syntax is as follows.

content.prevXml: <mxGraphModel><root><mxCell id="0"/><mxCell id="1" parent="0"/><mxCell id="9670" value="<font face="Courier New" style="font-size: 36px"><b><font color="#00d2b8">listName</font><font color="#f95700">.</font><font color="#0081c6">add(</font><font color="#00d2b8">element</font><font color="#0081c6">)</font></b></font>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;whiteSpace=wrap;" parent="1" vertex="1"><mxGeometry x="-510" y="90" width="360" height="20" as="geometry"/></mxCell><mxCell id="7559" style="edgeStyle=orthogonalEdgeStyle;rounded=0;html=1;exitX=0;exitY=0.75;entryX=0;entryY=0.75;jettySize=auto;orthogonalLoop=1;" parent="1" source="9670" target="9670" edge="1"><mxGeometry relative="1" as="geometry"/></mxCell></root></mxGraphModel>

content.text: Let's look at an example below.

content.text:
## Finding the Length of a List

The length of a list is simply the number of elements in that list. To find the length of a list, we can access the `length` property using `.` symbol. 

The basic syntax is as follows.
content.mdHtml:
Finding the Length of a List

The length of a list is simply the number of elements in that list. To find the length of a list, we can access the length property using . symbol.

The basic syntax is as follows.

content.prevXml: <mxGraphModel><root><mxCell id="0"/><mxCell id="1" parent="0"/><mxCell id="9670" value="<font face="Courier New" style="font-size: 36px"><b><font color="#0081c6">var</font><font color="#751a21">&nbsp;</font><font color="#00d2b8">listName</font><font color="#751a21"> </font><font color="#f95700">=</font><font color="#751a21"> </font><font color="#0081c6">[</font><font color="#00d2b8">elem 1</font><font color="#0081c6">,</font><font color="#751a21">&nbsp;</font><font color="#00d2b8">elem 2</font><font color="#0081c6">,</font><font color="#f95700">...</font><font color="#0081c6">,</font><font color="#00d2b8">elem n</font><font color="#0081c6">]</font></b></font>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;whiteSpace=wrap;" parent="1" vertex="1"><mxGeometry x="-510" y="90" width="940" height="20" as="geometry"/></mxCell><mxCell id="7559" style="edgeStyle=orthogonalEdgeStyle;rounded=0;html=1;exitX=0;exitY=0.75;entryX=0;entryY=0.75;jettySize=auto;orthogonalLoop=1;" parent="1" source="9670" target="9670" edge="1"><mxGeometry relative="1" as="geometry"/></mxCell></root></mxGraphModel>

content.text: Let's find the length of our `listOfVegetables`.
When you press RUN, the number **3** should be displayed because `listOfVegetables` has three elements.
content.mdHtml: When you press RUN, the number 3 should be displayed because listOfVegetables has three elements.

content.text:
## Adding a Single Element

We can add a single element to the end of an already existing list using the `add` method. The only condition is that the element you add must be of the same type as the elements of the list.

The `add` method has a single parameter which is the element you want to add to a list. The type of the parameter depends on the list you call the method on.

The general syntax is as follows.
content.mdHtml:
Adding a Single Element

We can add a single element to the end of an already existing list using the add method. The only condition is that the element you add must be of the same type as the elements of the list.

The add method has a single parameter which is the element you want to add to a list. The type of the parameter depends on the list you call the method on.

The general syntax is as follows.

content.text: Let's add another vegetable to our `listOfVegetables`.
When you press RUN, you'll see that the updated list now also has *cabbage* as an element.
content.mdHtml: When you press RUN, you’ll see that the updated list now also has cabbage as an element.

content.text:
## Adding Multiple Elements

We can add multiple elements to an already existing list using the `addAll` method. Again, the only condition is that the elements you add must all be of the same type as the elements of the list.

The `addAll` method also has a single parameter which is a list. The list should contain the elements you want to add to an already existing list. The type of the parameter is `List<dataType>`, where the data type depends on the list you call the method on.

In conclusion, `addAll` basically merges the elements of two lists into one. 

The general syntax is as follows.
content.mdHtml:
Adding Multiple Elements

We can add multiple elements to an already existing list using the addAll method. Again, the only condition is that the elements you add must all be of the same type as the elements of the list.

The addAll method also has a single parameter which is a list. The list should contain the elements you want to add to an already existing list. The type of the parameter is List<dataType>, where the data type depends on the list you call the method on.

In conclusion, addAll basically merges the elements of two lists into one.

The general syntax is as follows.

content.text: Let's add two more vegetables to our `listOfVegetables`.
content.mdHtml: Let’s add two more vegetables to our listOfVegetables.

content.text:
## Removing a Single Element

To remove a single element from an already existing list, we can use the `removeAt` method which removes the element at the specified index.

The `removeAt` method has a single parameter which is the index of the element you want to remove. The type of the parameter is `int`.

The general syntax is as follows.
content.mdHtml:
Removing a Single Element

To remove a single element from an already existing list, we can use the removeAt method which removes the element at the specified index.

The removeAt method has a single parameter which is the index of the element you want to remove. The type of the parameter is int.

The general syntax is as follows.

content.prevXml: <mxGraphModel><root><mxCell id="0"/><mxCell id="1" parent="0"/><mxCell id="9670" value="<font face="Courier New" style="font-size: 36px"><b><font color="#00d2b8">listName</font><font color="#f95700">.</font><font color="#0081c6">removeAt(</font><font color="#00d2b8">index</font><font color="#0081c6">)</font></b></font>" style="text;html=1;strokeColor=none;fillColor=none;align=center;verticalAlign=middle;whiteSpace=wrap;" parent="1" vertex="1"><mxGeometry x="-670" y="90" width="520" height="20" as="geometry"/></mxCell><mxCell id="7559" style="edgeStyle=orthogonalEdgeStyle;rounded=0;html=1;exitX=0;exitY=0.75;entryX=0;entryY=0.75;jettySize=auto;orthogonalLoop=1;" parent="1" source="9670" target="9670" edge="1"><mxGeometry relative="1" as="geometry"/></mxCell></root></mxGraphModel>

content.text:
If you know which element you want to remove but don't know it's index, you can use the `indexOf` method we discussed in a previous lesson to find the index of an element.

Let's find the index of 'carrot' and remove it from our `listOfVegetables`.
content.mdHtml:
If you know which element you want to remove but don’t know it’s index, you can use the indexOf method we discussed in a previous lesson to find the index of an element.

Let’s find the index of ‘carrot’ and remove it from our listOfVegetables.

content.text: The final `listOfVegetables` now only contains two elements, namely 'cucumber' and 'zucchini'.
content.mdHtml: The final listOfVegetables now only contains two elements, namely ‘cucumber’ and ‘zucchini’.

content.text:
## Removing All Elements

To remove all the elements from a list, we can simply call the `clear` method which takes no parameters.

Let's remove all the elements from `listOfVegetables`.
content.mdHtml:
Removing All Elements

To remove all the elements from a list, we can simply call the clear method which takes no parameters.

Let’s remove all the elements from listOfVegetables.

content.text:
When you press RUN, an empty list should be displayed.
